children.title: creation
children.comment: The created order, established as a sovereign decision on the part of God. The creation is dependent upon and under the authority of its Creator. Scripture affirms the role of both Jesus Christ and the Holy Spirit in the work of creation.

children.title: creation, origin of
children.comment: The free act of God based on his own wisdom and power, forming the whole natural order by his word.

children.title: God is Creator of the universe and everything in it

primaryrefs.comment: Genesis witnesses to order and progression in God's creative activity. The creation of Adam and Eve is not merely the end point, but the climax to the sequence.

children.title: The role of Jesus Christ in creation
The role of the Spirit in creation
The original creation was complete and perfect
Creation should cause people to worship God

seealsos.comment: God's power and deity is witnessed through the created order.

children.title: Sinners refuse the witness of creation
Believers receive the witness of creation by faith
creation, and God
children.comment: The natural world is sustained by God and speaks of God.

children.title: Creation is upheld for the good of humanity
God's sustaining power reserves the world for judgment

seealsos.comment: Time is being given for sinners to repent.

children.title: God has given humanity responsibility to preserve creation
Creation speaks of God's nature and character

primaryrefs.comment: This is not to suggest that animals can talk to human beings, rather it is a poetic device to stress what can be learnt from created things.

children.title: His eternal power and divine nature
His spiritual work in believers' lives
creation, renewal of
children.comment: God's creation, spoilt by sin, will one day be completely renewed. The old order will pass away and a new everlasting order established.

children.title: The passing away of the old order
Jesus Christ's destruction of all his enemies
The new heavens and new earth
The purity of the new creation
The creation of the new humanity
A new heart and a new spirit

primaryrefs.comment: ``new'' refers to the work of the Holy Spirit in renewing Christians as they believe in Jesus Christ. This renewing will be complete in the new creation.

children.title: The desire for a new body
The resurrection of a new body
The nature of the resurrection body
The absence of sorrow and pain
God will dwell with his people
life
children.comment: The state of being alive, characterised by vitality, growth and development.

children.title: life, human
children.comment: Seen by Scripture as the climax of the work of creation, life is a gift of God and is to be treated with reverence and respect.

children.title: The ultimate duration of life is unknown to people

seealsos.comment: Since all people are made in the image of God they are of value to him and should be so to each other

children.title: Life is to be lived for God
The termination of life by death is due to sin
life, animal and plant
children.comment: All living creatures and plants were made by God and are sustained by him.

children.title: Animals are cared for by God
Animal life is controlled by God
Animal life has been placed under human care
Animal life saved by Noah from the flood
Animals subsequently given to humanity for food
life, spiritual
children.comment: Life embraces more than physical existence; it includes humanity's relationship with God. Human beings come to life spiritually only through faith in the redeeming work of God in Jesus Christ. This spiritual life is a foretaste of the life which believers will finally enjoy to the full in the new heaven and earth. Life in the Spirit means keeping in step with the promptings and guidance of the Holy Spirit, and always being open to his gifts and empowerment.

children.title: The origins and nature of spiritual life
Spiritual life is the work of the Holy Spirit
Spiritual life unites believers to Jesus Christ
Spiritual life makes believers the children of God
Spiritual life brings people to know God
Keeping in step with the Spirit
A new way of life is made possible
Bondage to the written law is ended
Obedience to God is made possible
Gifts for those living in the Spirit
Gifts are given for building up the church
Those living in the Spirit receive revelation and guidance
The Holy Spirit sanctifies those in whom he lives
Through the Spirit, Jesus Christ lives in believers
The fruit of the Spirit is seen in believers' lives
Examples of life in the Holy Spirit
life, believers' experience of
children.comment: God is at work in all that happens to believers, whether to warn them, to draw them to himself or to do them good.

children.title: God has a purpose in all the experiences that believers have in life
Rejection of this conviction leads to despair
God uses every experience in the lives of believers for good
To test and exercise believers' trust in God
To purify and prepare believers for glory
In all of life's experiences believers should be thankful and trusting

seealsos.comment: Noah's sacrifice would, among other things, express his thankfulness

children.title: Believers do not merit the blessings they receive
life, of faith
children.comment: The way by which believers journey through this world and into the life to come. Jesus Christ himself is the way to life.

children.title: Life seen as travelling with God
Journeying from the old to the new
Sinners refuse to follow God's way
All other routes end in death
Those who travel God's way are blessed
Jesus Christ is the way to life
Entrance to the way to life
world, the
children.comment: Scripture understands ``the world'' in a number of senses. It initially refers to the world as God's good creation. However, that same world has now fallen into sin, with the result that it can be a threat to believers. Believers are called to live in the world, maintaining contact with it, while remaining distinct from it, and avoiding being contaminated by it.

children.title: world, as God's creation
children.comment: The heavens and the earth were created by God, and ordered by him and for him.

children.title: The world was created out of nothing

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ as the eternal Word is creator of all things.

children.title: The world God created was perfect
God created the world for a purpose
That people might worship and revere him

seealsos.comment: God reigns within the world he has made.

children.title: world, as fallen
children.comment: The world has fallen into sin and rebellion against its Creator. As a result, it has come under the power of Satan.

children.title: The world is under the power of Satan
He is prince of this world
He holds the world in his grasp
The world is opposed to God
Evil extends to the unseen world of the heavenly realms
It is opposed to God's wisdom
It is opposed to the life of faith
It is opposed to Jesus Christ's kingdom
It will be judged in righteousness
It will be judged by the saints
world, as redeemed
children.comment: Though fallen, the world is offered the hope of redemption and restoration through Jesus Christ.

children.title: Through Jesus Christ there is redemption and renewal for the world
The promise of a new heaven and a new earth
world, human beings in
children.comment: The world is intended to be the dwelling-place of humanity, as the height of God's creation. Human beings are organised within the world into groupings and nations and have a God-given authority to rule.

children.title: The responsibility of human beings to rule

primaryrefs.comment: ``subdue'' and ``rule'' do not give liberty to exploit and abuse but responsibility for caring for and bringing the best out of God's world.

children.title: The response of human beings to God's commission to rule
The ordering of nations within the world
The world as the object of the gospel proclamation
God sent Jesus Christ to this world
Believers are commanded to evangelise this world

children.comment: Human behaviour in the world is now characterised by self-centredness as a result of sin. Believers are called upon to renounce such sinful behaviour.

children.title: Human passion in the world is expressed in various ways
Though remaining in the world, believers are not of the world
Believers are to renounce the passions of the world
They bring no lasting material gain
abundance
children.comment: A state of plenty. Since Israel was often restricted in resources, abundance was an important feature of her future hope, and became a symbol of spiritual well-being.

cschildren.title: Material abundance a reward for obedience

children.title: Obedience not always rewarded in this way
The abundance of God's future blessing
beauty
children.comment: A physical or spiritual quality which brings pleasure to those who behold it. Scripture stresses the beauty of God himself and his creation, while noting that the beauty of the creation can lead away from God or become idolised.

children.title: Beauty and lack of beauty as external impressions
May lead to pride and lust

cschildren.title: The beauty of God as the joy of believers

children.title: chaos
children.comment: A state of complete disorder or confusion. The first stage of creation where, having brought something out of nothing, God had not yet brought order to the universe. This primeval chaos, often symbolised by surging waters, threatens to disrupt God's order at any time. God sometimes allows a return to chaos as judgment.

cschildren.title: God creates order out of chaos

children.title: God creates something out of nothing
God brings order to his creation
Life and order in creation must be sustained by God
The raging sea as a symbol of chaos

primaryrefs.comment: The raging sea is a frequent symbol of the chaos from which the world was created and to which it could return. Yet those whose confidence is in the God who brought order out of chaos have nothing to fear

children.title: Threatening nations are likened to the raging seas as bringers of chaos

primaryrefs.comment: A period of anarchy, when no spiritual or political authority was recognised in Israel

cschildren.title: God uses chaos as a judgment

children.title: Floodwaters as a symbol of the chaos of judgment
Panic and destruction characterise the chaos that follows judgment
dust
children.comment: Human beings were created from the dust by God and will return to it at death. Dust is therefore taken as a symbol of poverty, lowliness and humility. In Scripture dust is shaken off the feet to warn of future judgment, and is also used as a means of expressing grief.

cschildren.title: Human beings were created from the dust by God
We will all return to dust when we die

primaryrefs.comment: God's curse upon Adam affected all humanity

cschildren.title: Dust as a symbol of poverty, lowliness and humility
Dust as a simile for a multitude
Dust is shaken off the feet as a warning of judgment
Dust is used in expressing grief and repentance

children.title: heaven and earth
children.comment: An expression which in the original Hebrew refers to the whole of creation. It is frequently used in relation to God both as Creator and Lord in order to emphasise his power and authority.

cschildren.title: Heaven and earth in relation to God

children.title: He is the Creator of heaven and earth
He is Lord of heaven and earth

cschildren.title: The personification of heaven and earth
Allusions to the end of heaven and earth

children.title: nature
children.comment: God's creation, often with special reference to plant and animal life.

cschildren.title: The distinction between humanity and the rest of nature

children.title: God created human beings alone in his image
Humanity is the steward of nature

cschildren.title: God makes himself known through the natural order

children.title: orderliness
children.comment: In his creating, sustaining and saving work, God reveals himself as a God of order. Likewise, the life of his people and of society as a whole should be orderly.

children.title: Jesus Christ's coming was prepared in advance

cschildren.title: Orderliness in the life of God's people

children.title: Respect for leaders as part of God's order
God gives responsibility in his administration to men and women
Governing authorities are ordained by God
Those in authority are to be honoured
Order in the home and workplace

children.precomment: The archangel Michael:

children.comment: Evil spiritual forces; Scripture stresses the reality of demonic forces and recognises a number of categories to which they may be assigned. Jesus Christ's authority over such demonic forces is seen at work in his ministry and in that of his disciples.

children.comment: Scripture uses a number of terms to refer to demonic forces, stressing both their reality and hostility to God.

children.comment: Demons are opposed to the person and work of God and seek to lead human beings, including believers, away from him. For this reason, believers are forbidden to be involved with them.

children.comment: A title given to those angelic servants of God who are given specific tasks in furthering God's purposes among humanity. These tasks include the giving of revelations, guidance, encouragement, warnings and the execution of judgment on those who oppose God's purposes.

children.title: It was carried at most times

cschildren.title: The staff was sometimes a symbol of authority
God's miraculous power was manifest through Moses' and Aaron's staffs

cschildren.title: The lightness and fragility of straw
Sycamore-fig trees were plentiful in Judea
Thorns and thistles as the result of the curse of the fall

children.title: threshing
children.comment: The process of beating out or separating grain from harvested stalks.

seealsos.comment: Paul is adapting a humane OT law to the support of Christian workers.

primaryrefs.comment: A threshing-sledge was a board studded underneath with sharp stones which was dragged by oxen over the wheat ears in order to separate the kernels.

children.title: threshing-floor
children.comment: The place where winnowing and threshing took place at harvest time.

cschildren.title: The threshing-floor as a symbol of harvest
The threshing-floor as a symbol of judgment
A threshing-floor was the site of the Jerusalem temple

children.title: tree of life
children.comment: One of two trees situated in the centre of the Garden of Eden. It is also mentioned in Revelation, where it symbolises life and salvation.

cschildren.title: The tree of life in the Garden of Eden
The tree of life in Revelation
The tree of life as a metaphor

children.title: trees
children.comment: Large, woody plants with trunk, branches, leaves and roots, noted for their long lives. Scripture refers to many different varieties of tree.

children.title: As a symbol of permanence or long life
The trees of life and knowledge
As an example of distorted vision
unleavened bread
children.comment: Bread baked without yeast, often made because of insufficient time to prepare bread in the conventional manner. It was also eaten at the Passover Feast and was presented with sacrifices and offerings.

cschildren.title: Unleavened bread eaten to commemorate the Passover
Unleavened bread presented to God as an offering

children.title: vine
children.comment: A plant on which grapes grow, cultivated primarily for making wine. Jesus Christ described himself as the true vine, the source of life and growth for all believers.

cschildren.title: The vine as an image of peace and security
Laws relating to the cultivation of vines
The destruction of vines as punishment
Israel is described as a vine
Jesus Christ is the true vine
Vinegar as an acid, reacting vigorously with alkaline soda
Vinegar as a substitute for wine

children.title: It was offered to Jesus Christ at the crucifixion
vineyard
children.comment: A cultivated field or garden, sometimes surrounded by a wall, in which vines and other trees were grown. Israel is sometimes compared to a vineyard. Some of Jesus Christ's parables concern vineyards.

cschildren.title: Vineyards were sometimes surrounded by walls
Vineyards were associated with a settled, peaceful life
Vineyards were a sign of wealth
The produce of vineyards not enjoyed by owner

seealsos.comment: the parable of the workers in the vineyard
the parable of the tenants

children.title: weeds
children.comment: Uncultivated plants or shrubs, growing wild, often among cultivated crops or plants. Jesus Christ used the image of weeds in some of his parables to illustrate sin and worldliness.

cschildren.title: The presence of weeds indicates desolation and neglect
Weeds were a serious problem for the farmer
Some varieties of weed were painful to the touch
Weeds in Jesus Christ's parables
cschildren.precomment: The parable of the sower and its explanation:

children.title: wheat
children.comment: A cereal widely cultivated for use as food. One of the main agricultural crops in biblical times, it is referred to throughout the Scriptures and features several times in Jesus Christ's teaching.

children.title: The parable of the wheat and the weeds
wine
children.comment: Drink made from fermented grape juice, often drunk instead of water in biblical times. Scripture recognises the richness of wine and its value in bringing joy to people; however, it condemns the excessive drinking of wine, and recommends total abstinence in some situations.

cschildren.title: Wine as a sign of blessing
Lack of wine as a sign of God's displeasure
Wine as an alternative to water
The pleasant taste and effects of wine

seealsos.comment: Noah
Lot and his daughters

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ's miracle of water turned into wine

primaryrefs.comment: God's wrath is often pictured as a cup of wine to be drunk.

seealsos.comment: quenching spiritual thirst
illustrating judgment and the moral decadence of Babylon the Great

cschildren.title: Wine as a symbol of the suffering and death of Jesus Christ

children.title: winepress
children.comment: The vat in which grapes were trodden to produce juice for making wine. Scripture sometimes uses the image of treading grapes at the winepress to depict scenes of divine wrath and punishment.

cschildren.title: The association of winepresses with harvest

children.title: wineskin
children.comment: A container or sack, made from animal skin to hold wine. Jesus Christ used the image of old and new wineskins to explain the differences between himself and John the Baptist.

cschildren.title: Wineskins used to store or carry wine

primaryrefs.comment: New wine was stored in new wineskins, which expanded with the wine as it fermented.

cschildren.title: The parable of old and new wineskins

children.title: winnowing
children.comment: The exposing of grain to the air by either tossing or fanning so that the loose outer part is blown away. It is also used figuratively to refer to God's judgment.

cschildren.title: Winnowing took place at the threshing-floor

children.title: wood
children.comment: Trunks and branches of trees used as raw material for various objects and as fuel for burning. Acacia wood was used extensively in the tabernacle and olive wood in the temple.

children.title: yeast
children.comment: A raising agent commonly used in bread. Bread that was required quickly was baked without yeast, as at the first Passover, commemorated annually in the Feast of Unleavened Bread. Although some non-meat offerings contained yeast, it could not be burned on the altar.

cschildren.title: Unleavened bread was made without yeast
The consumption of yeast was prohibited during the Feast of Unleavened Bread
Sacrifices burned on the altar were not to contain yeast
Yeast as an image of the kingdom of God
Metaphorical references to yeast as something evil
